definition: a function that has access to variables in its outer (enclosing) scope, even after the outer function has returned.
the technique of transforming a function that takes multiple arguments into a function that takes a single argument.
a technique used to limit the rate at which a function is called.
the behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope.
an Immediately Invoked Function Expression is a function that is executed immediately after it is created.
a technique used to speed up computer programs by storing the results of expensive function calls and returning the cached result when the same inputs occur again.
a function that wraps an expression to delay its evaluation.
an object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.
a function passed as an argument to another function to be executed later.
a function that takes one or more functions as arguments, and/or returns a function as its result.
the act of combining simple functions to build more complicated ones.
the process of fixing a number of arguments to a function, producing another function of smaller arity.
